review.title: Extracting Biomolecular Interactions Using Semantic Parsing of Biomedical Text
review.abstract: We advance the state of the art in biomolecular interaction extraction with three contributions: (i) We show that deep, Abstract Meaning Representations (AMR) significantly improve the accuracy of a biomolecular interaction extraction system when compared to a baseline that relies solely on surface- and syntax-based features; (ii) In contrast with previous approaches that infer relations on a sentence-by-sentence basis, we expand our framework to enable consistent predictions over sets of sentences (documents); (iii) We further modify and expand a graph kernel learning framework to enable concurrent exploitation of automatically induced AMR (semantic) and dependency structure (syntactic) representations. Our experiments show that our approach yields interaction extraction systems that are more robust in environments where there is a significant mismatch between training and test conditions.
histories: Appearing in Proceedings of the Thirtieth AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-16)
review.COMMENTS: Appearing in Proceedings of the Thirtieth AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-16)
review.SUBJECTS: cs.CL cs.AI cs.IR cs.IT cs.LG math.IT

sections.heading: II. PROBLEM STATEMENT
sections.text: Consider the sentence "Mutant Ras proteins, therefore, accumulate with an increased GTP-bound fraction," which describes a "binding" interaction between a protein "Ras" and a small-molecular "GTP." We want to extract this interaction. In our presentation, motivated by BioPAX [12], an interaction refers to either i) an entity that causes state changes to another entity; or ii) an entity that binds / dissociates with another entity to form / break a complex, while optionally also being influenced by a third entity. An entity can be of any kind that exists in a biopath, such as protein, complex, enzyme, etc., although we are referring here to an entity of all valid types simply as a protein.

sections.heading: A. AMR Biomedical Corpus
sections.text: Abstract Meaning Representation, or AMR, is a semantic annotation of single / multiple sentences [3]. For example," attachment, "" attachment, "and" attachment "correspond to the same concept of" bind-01. We trained an English-English-English-English-English-English-English-English consortium [31] on two manually commented corpora: i) a corpus of generic 17k domain sets, including message wire and web text, as published by the Linguistic Data Consortium, and ii) 3.4k systems of biological sentences, including more biological constituents of the central plexus, are generally referred to as the" Medreative Papers "of the Medreative and Biological Fragment.

sections.heading: B. Extracting Interactions
sections.text: Fig. 1 represents a manual AMR annotation of a sentence that has two highlighted entity nodes called "RAS" and "GTP." These nodes also have entity annotations, "enzyme" and "small molecule." The interaction "RAS-binds-GTP" is extracted from the highlighted subgraph under the node "bind-01." In the subgraph, the relationship between the interaction node "bind-01" and the entity nodes "Ras" and "GTP" is defined as interaction by two edges labeled "ARG1" and "ARG2." In addition, in the subgraph, we assign the roles "interaction type," "protein protein" protein, "" bind-01, "" a problem "that we present in the interaction process" G1. "

Originally, this kernel uses an identity function on two node labels when calculating the similarity between these two nodes. Instead, we propose to use vector space to embed the node labels [10, 26], and then define a sparse RBF kernel on the node label vectors. sections.heading: V. CROSS REPRESENTATION SIMILARITY
sections.text: In the previous section, we proposed a novel algorithm for extracting interactions from AMRs [31]. We will see in our experiments (Section VI) that AMRs provide better extraction accuracy compared to SDGs. This result suggests that the use of deep semantic characteristics is very useful for the extraction task. On the other hand, one may wonder whether the common use of semantic (AMRs) and syntactic (SDGs) parses can improve the extraction accuracy of shallow parsers such as SDGs. There are some intuitive observations that justify the common approach: i) shallow syntactic parses may be sufficient for the correct extraction of a subset of interactions; ii) semantic parsers may make errors that are avoidable in syntactic domains.

sections.heading: VI. EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: We evaluated the proposed algorithm on the basis of two data sets.

sections.heading: A. Data Sets
sections.text: 1) PubMed45: This dataset contains 400 manual and 3k automatic analyses of AMRs (and 3.4k automatic analyses of SDGs) 7; AMRs automatic analyses are taken from 45 PubMed articles on cancer. From the 3.4k AMRs, we extract 25k subgraphs representing 20k interactions (valid / invalid); the same is true for SDGs. These are our primary data for evaluation. We found that for both AMR- and SGD-based methods, part of the extraction error is due to poor detection of designated entities. To minimize this effect and to isolate errors specific to the extraction methods themselves, we follow the footsteps of previous studies and take a filtered subset of interactions (approximately 10k of 20k). We refer to this dataset as "PubMed45" and the superset of 2000 datasets that are immediately available to us as "PubERS" (the pair of 2000).

sections.heading: B. Evaluation settings
sections.text: In a typical assessment scenario, the validation by random subsamples of described interactions (at the record level) is performed for a test subset and the rest is used as a training set. This sentence-level validation approach is not always suitable for extracting protein interactions [35], because interactions from a single / multiple sentences in a document can be correlated. Such correlations can lead to information leaks between training and test sets (artificial match that does not occur in real settings). In [27], for example, the reported F1 score from random validation in the AIMed data is about 0.5. Our algorithm, even using SDGs, gives 0.66 F1 scores in these settings. However, performance decreases significantly when an independent test document is processed. Therefore, we divide the data sets at the document level into about 10 subgroups, so that there is a minimum test set selected between a classification subset and the rest of a subset of the education.

sections.heading: C. Evaluation Results
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: VII. RELATED WORK
sections.text: Pattern-matching-based systems (either manual or semi-automatic) generally provide high precision but little memory [20, 22, 19, 18]. Kernel-based methods based on different folding cores were also developed for the extraction task [35, 1, 27]. Some approaches work more on strings than on parses [27]. The aforementioned work relies on either text or its flat parses, none of which uses semantic parsing for the extraction task. In addition, most work only looks at protein-protein interactions ignoring interaction types. Some recent work used remote monitoring to obtain a large dataset of protein pairs for their experiments [23]. Document-level extraction has been researched in the past [32, 7]. This work classifies at the sentence level and then combines the sequences at the sentence level, while we propose to jointly conclude all sentences at the document level.

sections.heading: VIII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In summary, we have developed and validated a method for extracting biomolecular interactions using deep semantic parses of biomedical texts (AMRs) for the first time. We have introduced a new algorithm based on Graph Distribution Kernel (GDK) to extract document-level interactions from a series of AMRs in a document. GDK can work with both AMR and SDG parses of sentences. The logic behind this hybrid approach is that while both parses are not perfect, their combination can provide superior results. In fact, our experimental results suggest that the proposed approach outperforms baselines, especially in the practically relevant scenario where there is a discrepancy between the training and the test sets. To facilitate the common approach, we have proposed a novel method for embedding edge vector space to assess similarities between different parent types.

sections.heading: IX. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: It is our pleasure to acknowledge fruitful discussions with Michael Pust, Kevin Knight, Shuyang Gao, Linhong Zhu, Neal Lawton, Emilio Ferrara and Greg Ver Steeg. We are also grateful to anonymous critics for their valuable feedback.

metadata.abstractText: We advance the state of the art in biomolecular interaction extraction with three contributions: (i) We show that deep, Abstract Meaning Representations (AMR) significantly improve the accuracy of a biomolecular interaction extraction system when compared to a baseline that relies solely on surfaceand syntax-based features; (ii) In contrast with previous approaches that infer relations on a sentence-by-sentence basis, we expand our framework to enable consistent predictions over sets of sentences (documents); (iii) We further modify and expand a graph kernel learning framework to enable concurrent exploitation of automatically induced AMR (semantic) and dependency structure (syntactic) representations. Our experiments show that our approach yields interaction extraction systems that are more robust in environments where there is a significant mismatch between training and test conditions.
